bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Philip Showalter Hench, January 31, 1938

div1.p: Andrus offers his cooperation in Hench's project and encloses a list of the yellow fever volunteers.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Philip Showalter Hench, January 31, 1938
div1.opener:
J. H. Andrus
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
1-31-38.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
I recently had a letter from John J. Moran in which
he asked for names and addresses of surviving yellow
fever volunteers. He said he wanted the list for
you - so it is quite probable you will receive the
data from him before this reaches you.

That you are writing on the work of Major Reed is
very interesting. I hope that I may have the
pleasure of reading the work when it is completed.

I have started several times to write on this sub-
ject - from the point of view of the “human guinea
pig” - but, each time, have given the idea up for
the reason that I found it impossible to deal with
my experiences without a degree of self-dramatization
that would make ANY reader reach for the insect-
exterminator.

As a private in the Hospital Corps, stationed at the
point where the work of the Board was carried on -
Columbia Barracks - I was detailed for duty with the
Board. My work wasvin the shack used by Major
Reed and Dr. Carroll as a laboratory. While I
was busy “raising” and feeding mosquitoes and going
about other work in the laboratory, I know heard
these two discussing the work of the Board by the
hour. The mosquito jars and their microscopes
were in the same samll room. They both spent
many hours trying to “find” the “bug” that causes
the disease.

If I can be of any service to you - you have but to
command. I have been bedfast since March, 1932,
and have plenty of time on my hands.
